finish.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to complete the last part of something that you are doing
finish.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: You can’t go anywhere until you’ve finished your homework.
Have you finished that book yet?
I finished typing the report just minutes before it was due.
finish.translation[0].definitions[1].def: when an event, activity, or period of time finishes, it ends, especially at a particular time
finish.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The football season finishes in May.
finish.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to eat or drink all the rest of something, so there is none left
finish.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to complete an event, performance, piece of work etc by doing one final thing
finish.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: The party finished with a sing-song.
I would like to finish by thanking you all for your help.
finish.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to be in a particular position at the end of a race, competition etc
finish.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: He finished second in the 100 metres, behind Ben Johnson.
finish.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to take away all of someone’s strength, energy etc
finish.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: Another run like that would just about finish me.
finish.translation[0].definitions[6].def: to completely use up the supply of something, especially food
finish.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: The ice cream’s finished – can you get some more?
finish.translation[0].definitions[7].def: to give the surface of something, especially wood, a smooth appearance by painting, polishing, or covering it
finish.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: The furniture had been attractively finished in a walnut veneer.
finish.translation[0].note_box[0].items[: Finish is followed by an -ing form, not an infinitive You say
He finished to clean the kitchen
Finish belongs to a group of verbs where the same noun can be the subject of the verb or its object
In this sentence, ‘his speech’ is the object of finish
He finished his speech with a joke
In this sentence, ‘his speech’ is the subject of finish
His speech finished with a joke
finish.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: finish
to complete the last part of something that you are doing
Have you finished your homework?
The builders say they should have finished by Friday.
to finish making or doing something that has taken a long time to finish
The new bridge will be completed in two years’ time.
She has just completed her PhD.
finalize
to do the last things that are necessary in order to settle a plan or agreement in a satisfactory way
A spokesman said that they were hoping to finalize an agreement in the near future.
conclude
to officially finish something
The police have now concluded their investigations.
Ralph Ellis, Managing Director, concluded the conference with a review of the trading year.
wrap something up
to finish something successfully – used especially about agreements or sports competitions
Negotiators are meeting on Friday to wrap up the deal.
Liverpool had several chances to wrap up the game.
round something off
to do something as a way of ending a day, an evening, an event etc in an enjoyable or suitable way
They rounded off the day with a barbecue at the beach.
A concert in the park is being organized to round off the programme of events.
get it over with/get it over and done with
to do something that you have to do now, so that it is finished and you can stop worrying about it
Let’s go and do the shopping now and get it over with.
Just tell him how you feel and get it over and done with.
be done/be through
if you are done, you have finished – used especially when other people are waiting for you
We’re nearly done.
We should be through in half an hour.
be through with something/be done with something
to have finished using something – used especially when other people are waiting to use it
I’m done with the file.
I’ll let you know when I’m through with it.
tie up the loose ends
to finish dealing with the final details of something, so that is all finished
‘Is the talk ready?’ ‘I just need to tie up a few loose ends.’
finish.translation[1].definitions[0].def: the end or last part of something
finish.translation[1].definitions[0].not: a close finish (=an end of a race where two competitors are very close to each other)
finish.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: I was watching the race but I didn’t get to see the finish.
The day was a disaster from start to finish (=from the beginning until the end).
I won’t walk out – I like to see things through to the finish.
finish.translation[1].definitions[1].def: the appearance of the surface of an object after it has been painted, polished etc
finish.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: That table has a beautiful finish.
finish.translation[2].definitions[0].def: if shares etc finish at a certain level or price on a financial market, they are at that level or price when trading ends for the day
finish.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Shares finished marginally weaker, with the All Ordinaries index down 3.1 points at 1,772.5.
The FTSE 100 index finished 16.4 points lower at 2,342.1.
